metadata.title: Weibo-COV: A Large-Scale COVID-19 Social Media Dataset from Weibo

abstract.text: With the rapid development of COVID-19, people are asked to maintain "social distance" and "stay at home". In this scenario, more and more social interactions move online, especially on social media like Twitter and Weibo. People post tweets to share information, express opinions and seek help during the pandemic, and these tweets on social media are valuable for studies against COVID-19, such as disease surveillance. Therefore, in this paper, we release Weibo-COV 1 , a first largescale COVID-19 social media dataset from Weibo, covering more than 30 million tweets from 1 November 2019 to 30 April 2020. Moreover, the field information of the dataset is very rich, including basic tweets information, interactive information, location information and retweet network. We hope this dataset can promote studies of COVID-19 from multiple perspectives and enable better and faster researches to combat the spread of this disease.

body_text.text: At the beginning of writing, COVID-19, an infectious disease caused by a coronavirus discovered in December 2019, also known as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has infected 4,517,399 individuals globally with a death toll of 308,515 (Doctor, 2020) . Under the circumstances, the physical aspects of connection and human communication outside the household among people are limited considerably and mainly depend on digital device like mobile phone or computers (Abdul-Mageed et al., 2020) . In this kind of scenario, people will stay at home and spend more time on the social media communication. The social media plays an important role for people sharing information, expressing opinions and seeking help (Lopez et al., 2020) , which makes social media platforms like Weibo, Twitter, Facebook and Youtube a more crucial sources of information during the pandemic.

In the previous studies, social media was consider as a valuable data source for studies against disease, like uncovering the dynamics of an emerging outbreak(Zhang and Centola, 2019), predicting the flu activity and disease surveillance (Jeremy et al., 2009) . For example, some studies facilitate better influenza surveillance, like early warning and outbreaks detection (Kostkova et al., 2014; De Quincey and Kostkova, 2009) , forecast estimates of influenza activity (Santillana et al., 2015) and predict the actual number of infected cases (Lampos and Cristianini, 2010; Szomszor et al., 2010) . Therefore, it is necessary to make the relevant social media datasets freely accessible for better public outcomes to facilitate the related studies of COVID-19.

In this paper, we release Weibo-COV, a first large-scale COVID-19 social media dataset from Weibo (one of the most popular Chinese social media platform), covering more than 30 million tweets from 1 November 2019 to 30 April 2020. Specifically, unlike the conventional API or advanced searching method to retrieve data, which limit large data access, we first build a high-qulity Weibo active user pool with 20 million users from over 250 general users, then collect all active users' tweets during the time period and filter out tweets related to COVID-19 by our selected 179 keywords. Moreover, the fields of tweets in the dataset is very rich, including basic tweets information, interactive information, location information and retweet network. We hope this dataset can promote studies of COVID-19 from multiple perspectives and enable better and faster researches to combat the spread of this disease. At present, given specified keywords and a specified period, we have two methods for constructing Weibo public opinion datasets: (1) Based on advanced search interface of Weibo, however, due to the limitation of the Weibo search interface, we can only obtain up to 1,000 tweets with a specified keyword and a specified period, making it difficult to build large-scale datasets.

(2) Traversing all Weibo users, collecting all their tweets in a specified period, and filting tweets with specified keywords. However, traversing billions of Weibo users requires much resources and time, making it inefficient to build datasets.

To bypass these limitations, we propose a novel method to construct Weibo public opinion datasets, which can significantly improve the crawling efficiency while maintaining the big size of datasets. Specifically, our method is based on the above method (2), but we first build and dynamically maintain a high-quilty Weibo active user pool (just a small part of all users), and then we only traverse these users and collect their all tweets with specified keywords in a specified period.

Based on init seed users and continuous expansion through social relationships, we first build a Weibo user pool including more than 250 million users. The active Weibo user pool is constructed based on Weibo user pool and follow 2 rules: (1) the number of followers, fans and tweets are all more than 50;
(2) the latest tweet is posted in 30 days.
Finally, we build a Weibo active user pool with 20 million users, accounting for 8% of the total number of weibo users.

As described in the collection strategy (Section 2.1), we set the time period from 0:00 December 1, 2019 (GMT+8, the date of the first diagnosis) to 23:59 April 30, 2020 (GMT+8), and design a total of 179 keywords in this period. These keywords are comprehensive and rich, covering related terms such as coronavirus and pneumonia, as well as specific locations (e.g., "Wuhan"), drugs (e.g, "remdesivir"), preventive measures (e.g., "mask"), experts and doctors (e.g., "Zhong Nanshan"), government policy (e.g, "postpone the reopening of school") and others (see A.1 for a complete list). Specifically, based on 20 million Weibo active user pool, we first collect a total of 569,829,866 tweets posted by these users in the set period. Subsequently, we filter these tweets by COVID-19 related keywords and finally obtain 33,519,644 tweets. These tweets constitute our final dataset.
Each tweet in the dataset consists of the following 9 fields:

• id: the unique identifier of the tweet It can be observed that fields of tweets in the dataset is very rich, covering the basic information ( id, crawl time, content), interactive information (like num, repost num, comment num), location information (location map info) and retweet network (origin weibo).
Therefore, this dataset can be analyzed in a multitude of ways.

As shown in Table 1 , Weibo-COV contains a total of 33,519,644 tweets, including 895,012 tweets with geographic location information and 6,586,969 original tweets, and the number of deduplication users in the entire dataset is 8,876,036.

The distribution of the number of tweets by day is shown in Figure 1 . It can be found that from December 1, 2019 to January 18, 2020, the number of COVID-19 related tweets is very small (less than 5K) and may include some noise data. Since January 19, 2020, the number of COVID-19 related tweets increase rapidly and maintain at least 200,000 per day.

Noting that the data on April 4, 2020 is particularly striking and the number of tweets on that day exceeds 1.6 million. Because that day is China's Qingming Festival, and a national mourning was held for the compatriots who died in the epidemic. People posted or reposted a lot of mourning tweets on Weibo on that day.

As shown in Figure 2 , we plot location distribution of tweets with location information on April 4, 2020. It can be seen that tweets are distributed in various places around the world, including Asia, Europe, Australia and America. Among them, countries in East Asia, especially China are relatively densely distributed.

Therefore, although the Weibo platform is a Chinese social media platform, the location of tweets in Weibo-COV is concentrated in China, but it is not limited to China and includes almost the entire world.

As shown in Figure 3 , we select four days of tweets data at different stages of the epidemic development and draw word clouds. It can be seen from the word cloud that COVID-19 was first discovered in Wuhan in the early days (2019-12-31, "unexplained pneumonia in Wuhan"), then the virus quickly broke out in China (2020-01-31, "epidemic prevention and control"), and then the Chinese epidemic situation stabilized (2020-03-31, "isolation at home"), and right now the epidemic situation spread and broke out abroad (2020-04-30, "Cirque du Soleil in Canada").
Therefore, the content of the dataset runs through the development of COVID-19, and includes the impression of COVID on all aspects of society.

Several works have focused on creating social media datasets for enabling COVID-19 research. (Chen et al., 2020) , (Lopez et al., 2020) and (Abdul-Mageed et al., 2020) have already released multilingual datasets collected from Twitter. Given that China was the first country with a large-scale outbreak of COVID-19 and has stabilized now, therefore, COVID-19 related tweets on Chinese social media platform is particularly valuable for researches.

Only the dataset proposed by (Gao et al., 2020) includes tweets from Weibo, but their method based on Weibo advanced search interface, so they can not collect large-scale tweets from Weibo. Compared with our dataset, their overall size (less than 200K), time span (from January 20, 2020 to March 24, 2020), and number of keywords (only 4 keywords) are much smaller.

In this paper, we release Weibo-COV, a first largescale COVID-19 tweets dataset from Weibo. The dataset contains over 30 million tweets covering from 1 November 2019 to 30 April 2020 and each tweet with rich field information. We hope this dataset could promote and facilitate related studies on COVID-19.
